sentence: Despite a 38% rise since the March 23 lows of this year, at the current price of around $36 per share we believe National Instruments’ stock (NASDAQ: NATI) has more to go.

National Instruments, which provides measurement and automation software and hardware products, has seen its stock rally from $26 to $36 off the recent bottom compared to the S&P which moved around 55%.

Its stock is lagging the overall markets, as investors are cautious about the impact of global economic uncertainty and lower consumer demand on several of the industries, which constitutes National Instruments clientele.
Further, its stock is down 14% from levels seen in late 2019.
National Instruments’ stock has partially reached the level it was at before the drop in February due to the coronavirus outbreak becoming a pandemic.
Despite the healthy rise since the March 23 lows, we feel that the company’s stock still has potential as its valuation implies it has further to go.
Some of this rise of the last 3 years is justified by the roughly 10% growth seen in National Instruments’ revenues from 2016 to 2019, which translated into a 96% growth in Net Income.

This unusually high growth in net income figure could be attributed to a couple of factors like gain on sale of assets, a significant jump in interest income generated from yields on cash, cash equivalents and short-term investments, lower foreign exchange loss, and decline in income tax rates after the enactment of the U.S Tax Act in 2017.
Although the company has seen steady revenue and earnings growth over recent years, its P/E multiple has decreased.
We believe the stock is likely to see some upside despite the recent gain and the potential weakness from a recession-driven by the Covid outbreak.
Our dashboard ‘What Factors Drove 47% Change In National Instruments Stock Between 2016 And Now?’ has the underlying numbers.
National Instruments P/E multiple changed from around 45x in 2016 to 34x at the end of 2019.

While the company’s P/E has decreased to about 29x now, there is an upside when the current P/E is compared to levels seen in the past years – P/E of 34x at the end of 2019 and 37x at the end of 2018.
So what’s the likely trigger and timing for the further upside?
National Instruments provides measurement and automation software and hardware products which are commonly used in areas like data acquisition, instrument control, and machine vision.
The company’s business model is very sensitive to the changes in the industrial economy.
Due to the Covid-19 pandemic, many of its customer’s industries have suffered losses, impacting their ability to manufacture products.
It could affect the demand for National Instruments products and services in the short term.
However, with the easing of lockdown restrictions in most of the world, the economy is likely to improve in the next few months.
This is also evident from the consumer spending data for May & June which shows a sequential m-o-m growth of 8.5% and 5.6%, respectively.
We expect that the same trend will continue in the coming months, positively impacting the industrial economy.
This is likely to benefit the National Instruments’ revenue trajectory over the coming months.
Additionally, over the coming weeks, we expect continued improvement in demand and subdued growth in the number of new Covid-19 cases in the U.S. to buoy market expectations.

Following the Fed stimulus — which helped to set a floor on fear — the market has been willing to “look through” the current weak period and take a longer-term view, with investors now mainly focusing their attention on 2021 results.
Though market sentiment can be fickle, and evidence of a sustained uptick in new cases could spook investors once again.
What if you’re looking for a more balanced portfolio instead?

Here’s a top-quality portfolio to outperform the market, with over 100% return since 2016, versus 55% for the S&P 500, Comprised of companies with strong revenue growth, healthy profits, lots of cash, and low risk.
It has outperformed the broader market year after year, consistently.
